awd_titl_txt: Scientific Studies from a Network of Sustainable, Robotic Observatories Across the Antarctic Ice-shelf:  A New Approach to Polar Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The near-Earth environment (Geospace) is mostly controlled by the Earth's magnetic field, which provides the Earth with protection from phenomena of electromagnetic nature, such as solar flares, coronal mass ejection, etc.; some of these events could be very dangerous and affect and even damage satellites, their instrumentation, and their communication with ground centers. However, the Earth's magnetic field has some specific regions where it is exposed to all these impacts from outer space. The polar caps are specific areas around the geomagnetic poles where geomagnetic field lines are open and directly interact with the interplanetary magnetic field (that is an extended magnetic field of the Sun). During strong geomagnetic disturbances, the polar caps increase their size - sometimes dramatically. Monitoring the Earth's polar regions, geomagnetic disturbances, currents that flow over these regions, polar cap boundary dynamics, etc., are important issues of space weather studies. Hundreds of magnetometers observe the Northern hemisphere polar cap and auroral zone on a regular basis. However, the Southern hemisphere has many fewer observatories. Having a large network of magnetometers for monitoring the geomagnetic environment is vital for understanding space weather-related events and their impact on environments, since the number of satellites in Geospace continues to grow very fast. 

One of the major problems in developing an observational infrastructure in Antarctica is the enormous difficulty for people to reach the region and to stay there. This factor makes any scientific project extremely expensive. Therefore, the development of Automatic Geophysical Observatories (AGO) that can function autonomously with minimal human interaction and maintenance provides a unique opportunity that can solve the problem. The arrangement of instrumentation produces data with a high potential to provide key advances in the field and that are highly demanded by scientific community. The science questions to be addressed in this research effort are: (1) Is the synoptic fluxgate magnetometer determination of the open-closed magnetic field boundary (OCB) valid; (2) What are impacts of solar wind structures on the OCB morphology; (3) How synoptic structures of GPS scintillations are relevant to OCB dynamics, and (4) Could the Iridium's Short Burst Data system be used to transmit fluxgate magnetometer data at a 1-hour time lag. The research is a cost-effective investment that will advance the state of knowledge of the Geospace domain and provide scientific community with vital observations.

por.por_cntn:
The Antarctic continent is the only location on Earth that is suitable for monitoring all areas of the Earth’s geospace environment, ranging from the sub-auroral zone, the cusp, and also deep in to the polar cap. With this in mind, the Automated Geophysical Observatory (AGO) effort started in the mid-1990’s with the intent of putting small, unmanned enclosures across the eastern Antarctic plateau.  These enclosures would provide shelter, power, and data telemetry for small-powered instrumentation. Throughout the latter 1990’ and through the 2010’s, the AGO shelters held a variety of instruments, most utilized for space weather and ionospheric and magnetospheric science, but also for meteorology and seismology.  

 

Over the past two and a half decades, however the cost of doing research in the deep field in the Antarctic has risen exponentially, whereas logistical support has remained relatively flat.  As an outcome, the cost of doing science in the deep field far exceeds that which is currently available to the USA National Science Foundation Antarctic Program.  It is at this time that we recognized that current level of logistical support is woefully inadequate, and thus this represents the last grant of the AGO program.  The AGO enclosures will be retro’ed in the coming years.

 

From this particular AGO effort we’ve conclusively demonstrated that it is capable of running remote enclosures across the east Antarctic plateau using only solar and wind power. These completely “green” systems are able to transmit data via Iridium, Iridium NEXT, and eventually Starlink systems.  Most recently, we demonstrated that data from the various AGO sites can be used to determine the location of the open-closed magnetic field line boundary and analyses it’s synoptic variability.   This is the only method that can synoptically do such measurements, as spacecraft and radar systems have their own temporal, spatial, and even data processing ambiguities.

 

Given the drastic logistical limitations currently in place in the US Antarctic Program, it is a loss to the broader US community that the AGO program is sunsetting.  The sites, if properly attended, would have enabled real time monitoring of the Earth’s geospace environment, and would provide crucial data that is directly applicable scientific, commercial, and military sectors of the US public.  Other countries have realized the resources enabled by the observations from the east Antarctic plateau, and in the future the US will likely end up following developments by foreign nations, particularly the Chinese and South Koreans.
